data.title: Day trip to the coastal city of C√°diz | Spain
data.meta_description: How to spend a relaxing day exploring the white coastal city of C√°diz, with tips on what to expect, see, and do - and some history too.
data.text:
With pristine white buildings gleaming along a turquoise shore, it‚Äôs easy to mistake the seaside city of C√°diz for one of Andalusia‚Äôs famous White Towns, also known as the ‚ÄúPueblos Blancos.‚Äù But technically, C√°diz is not considered one of the 19 Pueblos Blancos even though it shares many of their characteristics, such as whitewashed houses that stand out against the scenery, narrow streets that lead to cute town squares, and a relaxed vibe that conceals a complex history.

We visited C√°diz for a few reasons. First, it‚Äôs a picturesque city surrounded on three sides by water (the Gulf of C√°diz which flows into the Atlantic ocean), meaning it has beaches! Second, it‚Äôs less touristy so it‚Äôs a great place to experience the local culture and cuisine. And third, it was easy to get to from where we were staying in Seville (you can do a day trip there!).

Now, as calm and quaint as C√°diz is today, it was once a major stronghold that launched explorers, lured traders, and fought invaders.

Section overview

Brief history ‚Üí What C√°diz was like centuries ago, and how Muslims shaped its architecture, trade, and cuisine

How to get there ‚Üí The fastest route and the best detours from Seville

What to expect ‚Üí Tips about the city's atmosphere, culture, and customs

Where to eat ‚Üí Halal-friendly restaurant recommendations for the freshest seafood tapas and luscious gelato

What to see ‚Üí A grand cathedral and the tallest tower for incredible views

A brief history: A port of prosperity and pillage

C√°diz is the oldest city in Spain. It was first settled by the Phoenicians in the 8th century BC and it has been continuously inhabited since then. From 711 to 1262, C√°diz was ruled by the Moors (Muslim Berbers and Arabs from North Africa and the Middle East) who called the city ‚ÄúQƒÅdis,‚Äù which means ‚Äúthe fortified compound‚Äù in Arabic.

During their 500 years in power, the Moors developed the city‚Äôs maritime trade by building shipyards and establishing trading routes that stretched across the Mediterranean Sea. They also constructed whitewashed houses that reflected heat and stayed cool in the searing summers. To improve agriculture, the Moors introduced new crops and water management techniques, including the use of aqueducts, canals, and reservoirs.

After C√°diz was conquered by Christians, it became a hub for Spanish exploration and military activity. Christopher Columbus set sail from C√°diz on two of his voyages. As a result, C√°diz became a target of Spain‚Äôs enemies. It was raided, looted, and almost burned completely to the ground. That‚Äôs why C√°diz has over 100 watchtowers!

One of C√°diz‚Äôs watchtowers‚Ä¶ as seen from another watchtower

This coastal city‚Äôs history was marked by periods of both prosperity and pillage. The Moors, who helped the city flourish, were eventually expelled but they had a lasting impact on its architecture, economy, and gastronomy. You can still see whitewashed homes, it remains a key trading port, and C√°diz‚Äôs most popular dishes are infused with flavors and spices from Moorish cuisine. Even its current Spanish name ‚ÄúC√°diz‚Äù is derived from its Arabic name ‚ÄúQƒÅdis.‚Äù

How to get to C√°diz from Seville

C√°diz is located 75 miles (121 kilometers) south from Seville. Saad and I rented a car and drove there and back. The drive is not hard or long - it took us just under an hour and half each way on the AP-4 highway, which is a toll road. If you don‚Äôt want to drive, the next best option is to take the Alvia high-speed train from Seville‚Äôs Santa Justa station to C√°diz Central station. The Alvia will get you to C√°diz comfortably (it has free Wi-Fi and power outlets at every seat) in about the same time.

Travel tip: As I mentioned at the beginning of this post, the city of C√°diz is not one of Spain‚Äôs White Towns (even though it looked pretty white to us ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è). However, the city of C√°diz is located in the province of C√°diz (C√°diz, C√°diz is not confusing at all, right?) and this province is home to tons of Pueblos Blancos that are worth checking out. If you leave early from Seville, I recommend stopping at Olvera or Setenil de las Bodegas because these White Towns are stunning and nestled in unique locations. You can drive to both in 1.5 hours from Seville, spend time wandering around, and then drive another hour to eat at C√°diz. Olvera is special because it‚Äôs a white village perched atop a hill with a towering cathedral, while Setenil de las Bodegas has historic houses that are literally built into the side of overhanging cliffs. We didn‚Äôt have time to stop at these villages, but I wish we did.

What to expect

When we arrived in C√°diz, the first thing we did was find a parking spot where we could leave our car for the day because C√°diz is best explored on foot. The fun part of visiting a charming place like this, which is off the beaten path, is to get lost in its maze of streets and stumble upon local shops, cozy cafes, and charming little plazas. The most memorable adventures don‚Äôt follow a strict schedule; they allow time for curiosity to lead the way.

Strolling around sunny C√°diz in my sunny skirt

Saad and I spent an afternoon doing just that and here‚Äôs what we discovered about C√°diz:

It‚Äôs a city of locals, not tourists. C√°diz is a commercial seaport, not a tourist destination. There are no big name hotels or global restaurant chains. This is the home of fishermen and small family-run businesses. If we ever saw a crowd on the corner, it was usually a group of friendly neighbors chatting away.

English is not widely spoken, but people are welcoming. Since C√°diz is not a tourist hot spot, many people do not speak English, but don‚Äôt let that deter you from visiting. The locals are not hostile towards tourists. Everyone we encountered was warm and we always found a way to communicate with them, whether that was through wild and wacky hand gestures, translation apps, or English menus. We actually liked hearing so much beautiful Spanish spoken around us - it adds to the city's authenticity.

When the weather is nice, everyone goes to the beach. We visited C√°diz on a hot day. The city seemed emptier than expected, until we went to the beach where we found its entire population sunbathing on the sand.

The atmosphere is laid-back and mellow. Similar to the rest of Andalusia, life moves slower here and revolves around simple pleasures, but that doesn‚Äôt mean C√°diz isn‚Äôt lively. There are plenty of markets and plazas lined with stalls - like Plaza Topete.

Afternoon siestas are part of the culture. Most shops (and some restaurants too) will shut down between 2 - 4 p.m. for the traditional Spanish custom of siesta so people can take a break, nap, or have a leisurely lunch with their families. Oh what a wonderful way of life!

There‚Äôs a nightlife scene. Things may be slower during the day, but the locals like to drink (C√°diz is known for its sherry, which is one of its top exports) and dance at night. My advice to Muslim travelers is to get on the halal train out of here before the sun sets because the Old Town turns into party town.

Lunch and dinner are served late. Lunch is usually served around 3 p.m. and dinner is served around 9 p.m. It‚Äôs not uncommon for restaurants to be closed between lunch and dinner hours, so plan your day trip to C√°diz accordingly because you don‚Äôt want to be bumbling around hungry miss out on eating in this city!

Where to eat

No matter where you stop on the way, save your appetite for C√°diz. Saad and I skipped all the detours to ensure we made it to C√°diz during lunch hours. Sometimes instead of our curiosity, we let our stomachs lead the way. I have regrets about missing the White Towns, but not the food because it was delectable.

C√°diz‚Äôs culinary landscape is a vibrant mix of Spanish and Mediterranean dishes that are rooted in history while also tasting refreshingly modern. Given the city‚Äôs coastal location and focus on fishing, the best thing to eat in C√°diz are seafood tapas. Tapas are small plates with small portions of food. They‚Äôre the perfect size for sampling a variety of dishes. We dined at Sopranis. It was a tiny, family-run restaurant tucked away on one of the side streets, so it wasn‚Äôt buzzing with patrons, but the food was fresh and delicious. Try their patatas bravas, seafood cannelloni, and prawn croquettes. If you‚Äôre feeling adventurous and want to try funkier more inventive tapas, I recommend La Candela.

Patatas bravas and seafood tapas at Sopranis

If you know me, you know I rarely skip dessert. So, what do I recommend for my fellow sweet-toothed travelers in this beachy Spanish city? Gelato of course! It‚Äôs creamy, cold, and easy to hold as you stroll through the streets or on the sand. The two best gelaterias in C√°diz are Heladeria El Limonero and Narigoni Gelato. Narigoni‚Äôs Kinder Bueno and cookie caramel flavors were our favorite.

Narigoni Gelato was so good, Saad didn't even take his spoon out of his mouth for this picture #classyguy

Travel tip: If you peel your eyes away from my cup of gelato in the picture on the left, and look at the background instead, you‚Äôll notice a cathedral. That‚Äôs C√°diz Cathedral, one of the main sites of the city. Conveniently, Narigoni Gelato is located right next to it so that‚Äôs why, of the two gelato parlors, I recommend going to Narigoni. You can grab scoops of sumptuous gelato, sit down at an outdoor table, and enjoy the chill C√°diz life under the shade of the imposing cathedral.

What to see

C√°diz Cathedral

Speaking of chill life, we didn‚Äôt come to C√°diz with a structured itinerary, but we did have a rough idea of what we wanted to see. With our gelato in hand, we started with the cathedral of C√°diz. This Roman Catholic cathedral was built with the new money that poured in during C√°diz‚Äôs golden age of trade in the 18th century. While it didn‚Äôt take as long as Gaudi‚Äôs Sagrada Fam√≠lia to be completed, construction of C√°diz Cathedral still took 116 years. The cathedral‚Äôs architecture is a mix of styles because construction began in the baroque style but ended in the neoclassical style.

C√°diz Cathedral pictured with the surrounding palm trees to show you the vibe‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶and a picture without palm trees for a better look at the architecture and towers

Travel tip: C√°diz Cathedral has two bell towers, one of which (Levante Tower) is open to the public. For a few bucks, you can walk up the helix ramp to get to the top of the tower to see panoramic views of the city and take a closer look at the rooftop statues. However, I recommend saving your climbing energy for another, even more famous tower (coming up next).

Torre Tavira

C√°diz‚Äôs booming trade also led to the construction of its watchtowers. Wealthy merchants built watchtowers on their roofs so they could monitor the arrival and departure of their ships, and protect them from maritime threats like pirates. There are 134 watchtowers still standing in C√°diz. The most famous one is Torre Tavira (named after its first watchman), located in the center of the Old Town with a height of 45 meters above sea level (the highest point in the city).

Like other watchtowers, Torre Tavira (a.k.a. Tavira Tower) was originally part of a well-to-do lord‚Äôs residence that has since been converted into rooms of exhibits. There‚Äôs an exhibit on C√°diz‚Äôs golden age of trade and Spain‚Äôs first Constitution, which was signed in C√°diz. There‚Äôs another exhibit dedicated to the tower‚Äôs camera obscura. If you have no idea what a ‚Äúcamera obscura‚Äù is (me) or think that it sounds like a Harry Potter spell (me again), let me demystify it. It‚Äôs basically an old-fashioned optical device that was used by artists like Leonardo da Vinci to project real-time moving images of what‚Äôs happening outside. Although outdated, Torre Tavira‚Äôs camera obscura is a unique way to see the city‚Äôs monuments.

You can stop at these exhibits on the way up to Torre Tavira‚Äôs viewpoint. Now THIS viewpoint is worth the climb because look at that fantastic skyline of C√°diz! You can see the cathedral‚Äôs gold-tiled dome and bell towers standing out amongst the flat roofs. How many other watchtowers can you spot?

The view from Torre Tavira

Travel tip: There is no lift (or wheelchair access unfortunately) in Torre Tavira. If you are able to climb, Torre Tavira is 9 stories tall and there are about 173 stairs to get to the viewpoint. It's not a difficult climb, especially if you stop at the exhibits, but I must warn you, it‚Äôs windy up there!

This picture was brought to you by‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶my airborne hat and flying skirt wardrobe malfunctions ü§£

The beach & coast

On our way back to the car, we decided to take the scenic route by walking along the beach and coast. La Caleta is the closest beach to the historic center. It‚Äôs a local favorite because it‚Äôs sandwiched between two castles on the coast, so even if you don‚Äôt swim, it‚Äôs a nice walk.

One of the entrances to La Caleta (I didn‚Äôt take a picture of the beach because it was crowded)

Views during our walk by the shore

Travel tip: La Caleta is small, but it‚Äôs a clean beach with plenty of shade and access to public restrooms. You‚Äôll need to bring your own towels though. If you stay long enough, we heard this is a good spot to watch the sunset.
